[[Sri Lankan High Commissioner to the United Kingdom]] }} [[General officer|General]] [[Deshamanya]] '''Don Sepala Attygalle''', [[Royal Victorian Order|LVO]], [[Aide-de-camp|ADC]], [[Imperial Defence College|idc]], [[psc (British Army)|psc]], [[Sri Lanka Armoured Corps|SLAC]] (1922—January 2001) was a [[Sri Lanka]]n [[Commissioned officer|military leader]], [[civil servant]] and [[diplomat]]. The longest serving [[Commander of the Army (Sri Lanka)|Commander of the Sri Lankan Army]] (1967â1977), he went on to served as the [[Permanent secretary]] to the [[Ministry of Defence (Sri Lanka)|Ministry of Defence]] and Sri Lankan [[High Commissioner]] to the [[United Kingdom]]. He is most notable for successfully crushing the [[1971 JVP Insurrection (Sri Lanka)|1971 Insurrection]] in a matter of months and becoming the first Sri Lankan army officer to be promoted to the rank of a [[General officer|four star General]]. He is known as the ''"Father of the Armoured Corps"'' and was [[Equerry|The Equerry]] to [[Elizabeth II|The Queen]] during her [[Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II|coronation]] in 1953. ==Education== Attygalle was educated at the prestigious [[Royal College, Colombo]] where he became the Head prefect, won colours in both athletics and rugby and was the Senior Sergeant of the [[Royal College, Colombo#Cadet_Contingent|Cadet Contingent of Royal]]. Thereafter he went on to the [[University of Ceylon]].[http://www.priu.gov.lk/news_update/Current_Affairs/CA200101/20010117SL_Army_commanders.htm Last post for two Generals] He graduated from the [[Staff College, Camberley]] in 1953 and the [[Imperial Defence College]] in 1966. ==Military career== With the out break of [[World War II]] seeking a King's Commission, he joined as a [[Cadet Officer|cadet officer]] taking the Sword of Honour at the Army passing out parade at [[Diyatalawa]] in 1941. Soon after he was commissioned as a [[Second Lieutenant]] in the [[Ceylon Light Infantry]] and underwent advance training in India. After the war, he was demobilized and severed as an Assistant Controller of Textiles and Assistant Controller of Exports and Imports. When the new [[Ceylon Army]] was established in 1949 he joined in and was commissioned as a [[Lieutenant]] in the 1 Battalion, [[Ceylon Light Infantry]] as a regular officer, promoted to the rank of [[Captain (land and air)|Captain]] on the same day he was assigned as [[staff officer]] in the [[General Staff]]. In 1950 he was appointed as [[Aide-de-camp]] (ADC) to [[Herwald Ramsbotham, 1st Viscount Soulbury|Lord Soulbury]], the [[Governor General of Ceylon]] and was promoted to the rank of [[Major]] in 1952. In mid 1952, he followed a Company Commanders' Course at the [[Warminster|School of Infantry, Warminster]] and a Land/Air Warfare Course at the School of Land/Air Warfare. Thereafter he was attached to the 1st Battalion, [[King's Own Yorkshire Light Infantry]], in Germany, serving with the [[Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe|NATO Forces in Europe]]. In 1953 he relinquished the appointment at the Army HQ general staff, left for the [[United Kingdom]] for Staff College and was thereafter seconded to the [[1st The Queen's Dragoon Guards]]. During this time appointed [[Equerry]] to HM [[Queen Elizabeth II]] at her Coronation and served as Military Liaison officer to the [[Sri Lankan High Commissioner to the United Kingdom|High Commissioner for Ceylon]] in United Kingdom. On his return to Ceylon he took up command of the [[Echelon Barracks]]. On 10 October 1955 Attygalle, raised the 1st Reconnaissance Squadron as the [[Cavalry|Cavalry Arm]] in the Ceylon Army in the traditions of 1st The Queen's Dragoon Guards. In 1958, the [[Squadron (army)|squadron]] was expanded to a [[regiment]] and Attygalle was appointed as its first Commanding Officer with the rank of [[Lieutenant Colonel]]. The 1st Reconnaissance Regiment became the core of the [[Sri Lanka Armoured Corps|Ceylon Armoured Corps]]. On 17 December 1955 a Combined Services Buddhist Mission led by Major Attygalle left for [[Burma]] by [[HMCyS Vijaya]], to represent the [[Armed Forces of Ceylon]] at the Buddha Jayanthi Commemoration Celebrations with them a gift of a Bo sapling. In 1962, he was promoted to the rank of [[Colonel]], he took up command of the [[Panagoda Cantonment]], whilst serving as Commanding Officer, Ceylon Armoured Corps. Thereafter he became the Commander of the [[Task Force Anti Illicit Immigration]] in 1963, later the Inspector of Training, Army Headquarters. He become the [[Chief of Staff]] of the Army in 1964 after relinquishing command of the Ceylon Armoured Corps and relinquished command of the Task Force Anti Illicit Immigration in 1965. On 1 October 1967 [[Brigadier]] D. S. Attygalle took over as the as Acting Commander of the Army after the retirement of [[Major General]] [[B.R. Heyn]]. Promoted to the rank of [[Major General]] he was confirmed as [[Commander of the Army (Sri Lanka)|Commander of the Army]] shortly. Under his leadership the army crushed the [[1971 JVP Insurrection (Sri Lanka)|1971 Insurrection]] within two months and was promoted to the rank of [[Lieutenant General]] on 4 April 1974 thus being the first officer of the [[Sri Lanka Army]] to hold this rank. When he retired on 13 October 1977 after having served for ten years as Commander, he was promoted to the rank of [[General officer|general]], thus becoming the first Sri Lankan army officer to be promoted to the rank of a four star General and longest serving Commander of the Army. ==Later life== Apron retirement from the army, he took up appointment as Additional Secretary, Ministry of Defence and Chief Co-ordinating Authority in the Ministry of Defence in 1977. In the early 1980s with the escalation of the [[Sri Lankan Civil War|Tamil Militancy]] he was appointed as [[Permanent Secretary]], [[Ministry of Defence (Sri Lanka)|Ministry of Defence]] and served as National Defence Advisor to the [[President of Sri Lanka]]. He played a major role during the [[Vadamarachchi Operation]] until Indian intervention stopped it midway. During this time he was the founding Chairman, Air Ports and Aviation Services and Chairman of [[Air Lanka]]. In 1990 he was appointed as [[Sri Lankan High Commissioner to the United Kingdom|High Commissioner for Sri Lanka]] in the United Kingdom. His [[military funeral]] in January 2001, was well attended by his family members (His wife Brighty, his son Suraj and his grandsons Damin and Shaminda), friends and colleagues who gathered to mourn his loss. ==Decorations == He was made a Member of the [[Royal Victorian Order]] (Military Division) (MVO) by Her Majesty the Queen in recognition of the services rendered by him, during her Majesty's visit to Ceylon in 1954 which was later upgrade to Lieutenant in 1984. For wartime service in World War II, he had earned the [[Defence Medal]] and the [[War Medal 1939â1945]], and for service in the Ceylon Army, he received the [[Ceylon Armed Services Long Service Medal]], the [[Queen Elizabeth II Coronation Medal]] and the [[Ceylon Armed Services Inauguration Medal]]. For service in the Sri Lanka Army, he received the [[Republic of Sri Lanka Armed Services Medal]] and the [[Vadamarachchi Operation Medal]] for his later service as Secretary of Defence. ===Honors=== * Attygalle was promoted to the rank of [[General officer|general]] upon his retirement in 1977. * He was awarded the title [[Deshamanya]] from the Government of Sri Lanka. * He was a made a [[Royal Victorian Order|Member of the Royal Victorian Order]] which was later upgrade to Lieutenant. * Doctor of Literature (honorary) by the [[University of Sri Lanka]]. ==See also== *[[Sri Lanka Armoured Corps]] *[[Sri Lankan Non Career Diplomats]] *[[List of Sri Lankan non-career Permanent Secretaries]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.army.lk/co.php Parade Commander Major B.R.
